awd_titl_txt: NSFSaTC-BSF: CORE: Small: Foundations of Lattice-based Cryptography
awd_abstract_narration:
Over the last two decades, lattices have emerged as a powerful mathematical basis for cryptography. For one, Lattice-based Cryptography has resisted quantum attacks while conventional crypto systems succumbed to it in the mid-90s. Secondly, Lattice-based Cryptography has been instrumental in realizing new and exciting functionality which is beyond the reach of conventional cryptography. The most notable examples, perhaps, are Fully Homomorphic Encryption (FHE) and general Attribute Based Encryption (ABE) which, respectively, allow us to compute on and achieve expressive access control of encrypted data. Finally, it has also been shown that basic lattice-based constructions such as digital signatures, pseudorandom functions and key exchange can be made very efficient, to the point that we now have growing interest from the government (NSA and NIST) and the industry (Google) in deploying lattice-based cryptographic solutions. Success in our endeavor will have implications beyond the cryptography: enabling new solutions for privacy concerns in a world where data and computations are increasingly being outsourced, as well as providing security in a post-quantum era.

The goal of this project is three-fold: (a) New Cryptographic Constructions from Lattices: although we have made great strides in constructing advanced cryptographic primitives such as fully homomorphic, attribute based and functional encryption on standard lattice problems such as the learning with errors problem, much is left to be done. Perhaps the most prominent goal is to come up with a construction of program obfuscation (and thus, nearly all of cryptography) based on the hardness of standard lattice problems; (b) Efficient Lattice-based Cryptography: we aim to improve the efficiency of existing cryptographic constructions, starting from pseudorandom functions all the way to homomorphic and attribute-based encryption, an endeavor that is of tremendous importance in translating theoretical advances into practically useful objects; and (c) Foundations of Hardness of Lattice Problems: we aim to advance and deepen our understanding of the hardness of cryptographically relevant lattice problems. The project involves a significant educational component that consists of designing new courses in cryptography, making the lecture notes publicly available, giving expository lectures, writing survey articles and monographs intended for a broad audience, organizing a seminar series and a workshop on lattices, and advising graduate and undergraduate students.

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of this project was to study the foundations of lattice-based cryptography, one of the most important and actively studied areas in modern cryptography. In plain words, lattices are high-dimensional regular grids of points, a mathematical object with an algebraic structure that gives rise to computational problems upon which secure cryptography can be constructed. Lattice-based cryptographic solutions enjoy the benefit of both (a) being extremely versatile, and therefore useful for constructing numerous primitives such as fully-homomorphic encryption (an encryption scheme that allows to compute on encrypted data) and attribute-based encryption schemes (an encryption scheme where it is possible to distribute multiple keys and assign permissions for each individual key on which messages it can and cannot decrypt); and (b) enjoying a unique level of security guaranteed by worst-case to average-case hardness reductions, and presumed resilience to quantum attacks.

The focus of this project was two-fold. First, we set out to study various aspects of lattice problems and lattice based cryptography including the complexity-theoretic foundations for the hardness of lattice problems, an important goal considering the push from both government (NIST) and industry (Google) to standardize and use lattice-based cryptography on an internet scale. Secondly, we aimed to push the frontier of constructing sophisticated cryptographic primitives such as fully homomorphic encryption, functional encryption and program obfuscation using hard lattice problems.

We believe that our collaboration has been quite satisfactory and fruitful, and made a substantial scientific contribution. 

In terms of intellectual merit, we undertook a sequence of projects resulting in papers co-authored by members of the US and Israeli teams, including students and postdoctoral researchers, which advanced the state of the art in the field. The most significant contributions are:

The major intellectual contributions are summarized below:

1. A joint work of PI Brakerski and PI Vaikuntanathan, and Noah Stephens-Davidowitz (a postdoc in PI Vaikuntanathan’s group) connected the hardness of the well known k-sum problem to the hardness of lattice problems. Thus we were able to show for the first time an average-case hardness result for the k-sum problem. This connection is instrumental in the study of average-case “fine-grained” complexity.

2. A joint work of both PIs with Lyubashevsky and Wichs shows the first worst-case to average-case connection for the Learning Parity with Noise (LPN) problem which is important in light-weight cryptography.

3. A joint work of both PIs with Tsabary (student of PI Brakerski) and Wee, we constructed the first private constrained pseudorandom functions as well as predicate encryption schemes from the learning with errors assumption. These are powerful cryptographic primitives that allow us to compute on encrypted data in various forms.

4. A joint work of both PIs with Lombardi (student of PI Vaikuntananthan) and Segev showed new ways to construct identity based encryption, leakage resilient encryption and circular secure encryption from new assumptions including lattice assumptions.

The broader impacts are summarized below:

1. A broadening of connections between lattices and other areas in theoretical computer science such as coding theory, fine-grained complexity, and adversarial machine learning, and a holistic look at the connection of lattices to problems in computer science as a whole.

2. Beyond the direct scientific advance via publications, the collaboration, interaction and exchange of ideas helped in inspiring scientific progress within each of the groups individually and with other collaborators, and was instrumental in training 2 students and 2 postdoctoral fellows at MIT.

3. PI Vaikuntanathan co-organized a week-long workshop on lattices at Bertinoro bringing together experts in the topic together with early-career students and postdocs. Particular attention was paid to the participation of women and scholars from underrepresented groups. For more information, see http://crypto-events.di.ens.fr/LATCA/index.html

3. Finally, the idea of organizing an entire semester on lattices at the Simons Institute at UC Berkeley was born during the period of activity of this grant. PI Vaikuntanathan organized such a semester which brought together over 50 researchers from all over the world, many of them students or early-career researchers. For more information on this program, see https://simons.berkeley.edu/programs/lattices2020
